sentence: Shares of salesforce.com Inc.CRM gained more than 3% in after-hour trade yesterday following strong second-quarter fiscal 2016 results and an upbeat full-year guidance.

The company's adjusted earnings (including stock-based compensation but excluding all one-time items on a proportionate tax basis) of 5 cents per share compared favorably with a loss of 5 cents incurred in the year-ago period.
Moreover, quarterly earnings came in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
Salesforce's revenues of $1.635 billion not only increased 24% year over year but also beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.599 billion.
Reported revenues also came above management's guided range of $1.59 billion to $1.60 billion.
The year-over-year improvement was primarily attributed to rapid adoption of the company's cloud-based solutions.
Also, higher demand for Salesforce ExactTarget Marketing Cloud platform, part of the Salesforce1 Customer Platform, contributed to the year-over-year revenue growth.

During the quarter, the company's cloud-based solutions were selected by a number of companies including Barclays plc BCS , BBC, Comcast Corp. CMCSA , Commerzbank, Cox, Ford, Genomic Health, GlaxoSmithKline, Honda, Honeywell International Inc. HON and Renault.
Among its business segments, revenues from Subscription and Support increased 23.4% from the year-ago quarter to $1.521 billion.
Professional Services and Other revenues jumped 31.9% to $113.4 million.
Geographically, the company witnessed revenue growth of 27.8%, 16.4% and 11.1% in the Americas, Europe and Asia, respectively, on a year-over-year basis.
Salesforce's adjusted gross profit (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization expenses) came in at $1.250 billion, up 21.1% from the year-ago quarter.
However, gross margin contracted 180 basis points (bps) to 76.5%, primarily due to increased investment in infrastructure development, including the expansion of international data center.

Adjusted operating expenses (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization of acquisition-related intangibles) increased 15.6% from the year-ago quarter to $1.190 billion, primarily due to higher investments in research and development, marketing and sales and general and administrative activities.
However, as a percentage of revenues, operating expenses contracted 530 bps year over year to 72.8%.

Salesforce posted adjusted operating income (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization of acquisition-related intangibles) of $59.7 million as against the year-ago income of $2.5 million.
The year-over-year improvement in adjusted operating income was mainly due to a higher revenue base and a drop in operating expenses as a percentage of revenues.
Salesforce posted adjusted net income (including stock-based compensation but excluding all one-time items on a proportionate tax basis) of $34.4 million or 5 cents per share.
Moreover, it fared better than a net loss of $31.8 million or 5 cents suffered a year ago.
Salesforce exited the quarter with cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities of $1.089 billion compared with $1.019 million in the previous quarter.
Accounts receivable were $1.068 billion compared with $1.906 million at the end of first quarter.
Total deferred revenue, as of Jul 31, 2015, was $3.03 billion, which increased 29% on a year-over-year basis.
During the quarter, the company generated $304.4 million in cash from operating activities and a free cash flow of $239.5 million.
Moreover, in the first half of fiscal 2016, Salesforce generated $1.035 billion cash from operating activities and a free cash flow of $899.3 million.
Buoyed by the splendid second-quarter results, the company raised the fiscal 2016 outlook.
Salesforce now expects revenues in the range of $6.600-$6.625 billion, up from $6.52-$6.55 billion, representing a year-over-year increase of 23%.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.545 billion.
Non-GAAP earnings per share for the fiscal year are now projected within 70-72 cents, up from 69-71 cents.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate stands at 15 cents.
Going ahead, Salesforce also issued the third-quarter guidance.
The company expects revenues in the range of $1.69 billion to $1.70 billion, reflecting a year-over-year increase of 22% to 23%.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.680 billion.
The company expects non-GAAP earnings per share in the range of 18 cents to 19 cents.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate (including stock-based compensation expenses) is 4 cents.
Salesforce concluded the second quarter of fiscal 2016 on a strong note, reporting better-than-expected top line and the bottom line which improved significantly year over year.
The robust top line was primarily backed by growth across all its business segments and Salesforce ExactTarget Marketing Cloud platform.
The company provided upbeat third-quarter and fiscal 2016 guidance.
The higher number of deal wins and geographical contributions were also encouraging.
We consider the rapid adoption of Salesforce1 Customer Platform to be a positive.
Overall, the company's diverse cloud offerings and considerable spending on digital marketing remain the catalysts.
Moreover, strategic acquisitions and the resultant synergies are expected to benefit over the long run.
In view of the increasing customer adoption and satisfactory performances, market research firm Gartner acknowledged Salesforce as the leading social CRM solution provider.
We believe that the rapid adoption of Salesforce's platforms indicate solid growth opportunities in the ever-growing cloud computing segment.

Although the company is growing reasonably in the cloud market, growth prospects have been rationalized to a considerable extent due to intensifying competition from International Business Machines, Oracle Corp. and SAP AG.
Moreover, currency fluctuations and increase in investments in international expansions and data centers could impact the near-term results.
